Buy the Hayne's or Chilton repair for your car!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

Are you in Yurop?

See, we have freedom of speech over here in Burgerland which means the FM band is full in any metro area. Even if you find a band that seems quiet, those little FM transmitters have a hard time competing with the low power station from a larger suburb 50mi away or the next big city 100-200mi away. Had a couple types in Chicago, even the more expensive Monster brand one, and that shit couldn’t compete with stations in Milwaukee or Gary or some bullshit Christian station downstate. Can’t imagine ever trying to use one in the Northeast.

posts.name: Greased Geese

>>26195289

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26195336
It’s nearly impossible to get a good signal because there’s always interference from FM stations. Especially the cheap ones that only have like 2 FM bands to choose from. And back in the day I even got good ones where you could pick any FM band and it was still super hard to get a station that came through clear without interference. God forbid you take a little road trip and you finally found a band that is like 90% clear, as soon as you get 50mi out and are heading towards another medium-large sized city, you’re going to start getting interference.

Maybe in like rural Alberta they will work well, or like a medium-large city without any major cities nearby like Billings, MT or Boise, ID. Try that shit in the Northeast or any metro area with more than a million people and there’s way too many stronger FM signals nearby.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Choice 1: buy a new motorcycle for 10k+ and pretend that nothing can break, just ride it and enjoy the time until it requires maintenance, suffer when it does.
Choice 2: buy a 30yo bike for 2k, ride it until something breaks, disassemble/reassemble it, learn to maintain it in depth, keep it until no spare parts can be found.

Choice 2 seems to be the most rational, being cheaper and less painful by the virtue of setting the expectations low. Why am I so tempted to look for a brand new bike?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26200266
You probably have water getting into the bulb socket or connector, or just latent moisture in the air is enough to short the led bulb on. Pack the bulb socket with dielectric grease or silicone paste. Pack any connector related to that circuit with dielectric grease. This prevents moisture from getting into the terminals and shorting the circuit.

Even if a connector has a rubber seal, moisture can still be getting in if the rubber is old or compromised. Especially on a motorcycle, it's a good idea to pack any suspect connectors and give at least a light coating on the terminals anytime you have a connector undone.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26199989
Thinking about a mid/late 90's 3 series convertible as a summer car. What pros and cons have you experienced?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26200042
I have a convertible as well actually, a 1995 325i. I bought the 93 sedan recently as an cheap winter car. Vert is a manual, sedan is autotragic unfortunately. I've had a great experience with both thus far.

Pros:
-Fun to drive
-Fun to work on
-Easy to work on
-the I6 sounds great
-generally reliable (Convertible is at 230k miles and sedan is almost at 247k, engine is strong on both and trans is going to shit on the sedan just because it's a piece of shit 4L30E)
-With stock suspension and a full interior it's still a very comfortable car

Cons:
-Cooling system issues are notorious on E36s, primarily the water pump which uses a plastic impeller, you should get one with a metal impeller as soon as you can
-As these are becoming old you have to start dealing with old car shit like brittle plastics
-They don't rust super bad but they tend to rust around the lifting points when they do, which kind of makes them a pain in the ass and a little sketchy to work under
-There were a lot of them made, but it's going to be a challenge to find a half decent manual example because of their reputations as drift cars and the drift tax, a little easier with convertibles though since they're worse for motorsports
-Parts can sometimes be stupid expensive, especially if you have to get them from overseas which is actually pretty frequent
-For convertibles, stay away from the fully electric tops, they are a bitch
-The interiors on the earlier ones were not BMW's best effort quality wise, a lot of them will either have the door panels jankily screwed in or just no door panels like my convertible
-Window regulators go out a lot (I haven't had any, just a common problem)

These two are the only two BMWs I've ever had but I can recommend ownership based on them. A lot of BMW hate on this board is unwarranted and gay.

hello /ovg/, I picked up euro truck sim 2 on sale and I'm immediately hooked.
I never really got into racing games until now. I also picked up asseto corsa on sale and im thinking about getting forza too.
What is the recommended set up? Im thinking of buying a logitech g29 wheel on sale, the controller is okay, but steering on a game pad annoys me. Additionally, whats up with shifters, it seems like those aren't that important, only for really serious players. Also will possibly will get a third monitor?
So any other racing sim dudes got some pointers?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26191706
Here's some handy dandy methodology for you.

>Buy G29/G920 on sale, don't buy the shifter unless it's a bundle for an amazing price. Turdmaster T150/TMX is also a good choice if you're poor.
>Play games at your desk with it. Play MULTIPLE more games, not just ETS2 and AC.

Did you enjoy it? Do you yearn for more?

>No
Sell your wheel or chuck it into storage until you get the next urge to vroom. Money pit avoided.

>Yes
Make space and buy (or build) a cockpit WITH A SEAT. No wheelstands or half-measure cockpits like the GTOmega ART. You want a nice and rigid aluminum extrusion chassis right from the get-go - they can handle things like the Thrustmaster rubber band wheels all the way up to the SC2 Ultimate. Cheaping out and buying the Chinesium box tube steel chassis from Alibaba will only end in tears. There are plenty of budget-friendly aluminum profile cockpits for sale depending on your location. Things like the Playseat Challenge or NLR Faggot-Lite are OK if you're tight on space, but not ideal. You get an insane amount of immersion and fun-factor with a solidly mounted seat, wheel and pedals on a sturdy chassis than you do with fancier gear bolted to a desk.

>But I don't have any space for a cockpit!
You have more important things to spend money on than pretend race car video games. Stick with the the desk wheel.

>Ok, I have installed the manchild race car setup in my house, now what?
Play games again. If you end up hating it after a month or two, all you have to get rid of is the cockpit, and you can go back to having the wheel at your desk whenever you get the urge to vroom. No $2000+ worth of gear to auction off, your time and money is saved.

1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26191706
>>26191812
2/2
If you decide to fully dive in after getting a solid cockpit, the first piece of gear queer kit you buy is a good set of load cell pedals. Then a shifter and handbrake, if that's your thing. It's at this stage where you should upgrade your monitor situation or get a VR headset. Only NOW should you upgrade your wheel; at this point in time you should skip belt wheels entirely and get a nice wheel like a Moza R9 or Alpha Mini to have something that will last you a long time, to avoid the pitfall of the R5 or CSL DD. Don't waste your money and time slowly graduating through every tier of wheel like I did.

Congratulations, now you're a fully fledged gear queer.

Any questions?

>>26191849
Triple monitors are a gigantic hassle to set up and keep running, and most games don't support proper surround functionality. It's not really useful unless you play things like iRenting and absolutely NEED your full peripheral vision. (although, if you're just using 1080p@60 screens you fished out of the Goodwill bin for $30, you can be my guest)
You can still have an amazing sim experience on a single 16:9 screen; it's what at least 90% of all players are using, and is the priority #1 format games are developed for. If you want to upgrade the monitor early I can personally attest to a single 21:9 1440p screen having a great money-spent-to-enjoyment factor.

On a Tesla? Its not the batteries, its the motor, and not from acceleration. Its from KERS.
Owners have been getting around it on tracks by disabling KERS, and fitting better brakes.

Car makers are going to solve this problem the only way they can just by throwing more stored energy at it.
If you can have 200kWh then achieving 4 or 5 miles a kWh becomes less important and you can spend some more energy on things like pushing radiators through the air to keep the powertrain cool, and of course having more stored energy means not necessarily having to recapture energy in the first place.
200kWh is the magic number because its about how much actual energy output a gas car with an endurance fuel tank can manage, but of course since battery swapping isn't allowed FCEV range extending solutions on cars with 60kWh batteries may ultimately prove more popular for motorsports.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26200070
$1900 from Bend OR to Newark NJ, went thru a broker named Vice Auto Transport who found the shippers Any Distance Inc, or at least that is who did final delivery. The car arrived without any damage which is the most important thing. The brokers are allegedly some of the better ones and their communication was good, but the industry is all fucked up. There is zero transparency, lots of middlemen, the car goes on several different trucks, it takes 2x as long as you expect (I missed christmas with family because this arrived 12/26- almost week late, after it took 7 weeks just for the broker to find a driver) . I got led on that it would be in before Christmas and then was never updated saying they were delayed; I had to call and hope they pick up (3/5 calls they did not pick up, when I texted they didnt reply, when I left a message they didnt reply)
There is a reason why rich people pay probably $15,000+ for a single vehicle hauling closed transport truck to take 1 trip with 1 car. That's the only way to have predictable service. Rob ferretti on youtube has a video ranting about car transport as he regularly used it between FL and NY for his business; he says they're all just a pain to work with and never meet their own time estimates. A friend of mine who used Montway brokers years ago says he saw via tracker that his shipped 1970 dodge dart was left in an unprotected public parking lot for a full week.

My recommendation is, if you ship something: expect it to take literally 3x as long as their estimate. This would have been similar or more expensive (not even including time) for me to fly and drive this 16-18mpg pig, so it was still the right move to ship, I'm just a bit rustled jimmies about missing Christmas.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Got a rust free truck & didn't want it to start rotting. I went with woolwax, got the thicker stuff thats more like grease, sprays for shit so have to put it on by hand. Standard stuff sprays well though. Nice thick coat on the frame.

All the more out of the way places got cosmoline, crc or amsoil. amsoil sprays stong & makes a bit of a mess so that went on the underside. crc sprys softer & has a very nice finish so used that on the door edges.

The inner rockers, inner fenders & inner doors got a good dose of 3m cavity wax,

Woolwax at some point I know will need touch up. I know I'll have to looke over where the cosmoline was & touch up where any rock chips were or woolwax it if it got thru the paint, ineers pannels wont be touched again.

From what I could tell all 3 were the best of products to use & from a little testing I did seemed to do their claimed job.

posts.com:
I run gas (87) but used to run an allotted amount of TCW3 in as well. E85 generally by what I've read doesn't do well long term without the proper changeovers. I've heard plenty of stories with increased wear, etc. etc. Ethanol is ethyl-alcohol so I believe it may run cooler? but the burn time is changed too so under detonation can be a issue as well. 65% as much energy as fuel. Yuck.

Ideally diesel is the way to go for ICE. Hydro above that. The biggest issue with engines is the hotter they run the better they run, but if they run too hot it can cause damage.

Personally I'd stay away from e-85 though. I run a full time shop and have seen what ethanol does to certain rubber compounds in a matter of months.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Moron. Ethanol is twice as crrossive. It will chew through your liners and seals across the system if the cars not rated or upgraded.

posts.name: OP
posts.com:
>>26202483
But did he actually show you the lines, gaskets and seals or did he just say to not use it?

>>26202485
>>26202503
Older fuel lines (pre 2001) can have problems with ethanol and some alloys could experience corrosion too. Everything afterwards should be fine, jap cars were already fine after 1990 if I remember correctly.
Ethanol has a enthalpy of vaporization that is 3 times higher than regular gas and therefore takes heat away from your engine.
Problem is like in my case where I didn’t make any ECM adjustments is that the engine runs lean since the energy density of ethanol is smaller and therefore combustion temperatures are higher, which makes me fear that the cat could suffer.

Hydro has even worse energy density (volumetric)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-64057742
26 DEC 2022

Police are solving only 1% of catalytic converter thefts, data suggests

Tens of thousands of catalytic converter thefts are going unsolved, with only 1% of cases resulting in someone being charged, figures obtained by the Liberal Democrats suggest.

Data from 20 police forces in England and Wales for 2017-2021 indicate a suspect was charged in only 548 cases.

Catalytic converters fitted in car exhaust systems reduce their emission of toxic gases and pollutants.

Thieves are attracted by the valuable metals the devices contain.

Police say converters can often be removed in under a minute, and are most frequently stolen in car parks, before being sold to scrapyards, online or shipped out of the country.

Hybrid vehicles are most commonly targeted as their metals are more valuable, but any vehicle can be at risk of catalytic converter theft.

cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26200890

The Home Office says it has national programmes to target metal theft, including catalytic converters.

The police figures were disclosed in response to a Freedom of Information request.

In the 20 police areas where full information was provided, a total of 50,223 thefts of catalytic converters were reported in the five-year period.

Full figures from some of the biggest forces - including West Midlands Police and Greater Manchester Police - were not available.

In the 20 force areas surveyed, the number of thefts surged from 742 reported in 2017 to 19,451 in 2020, before falling in 2021 - the first full year of the Covid pandemic - to 15,780.

By far the highest number of thefts from 2017-2021 - 36,586 - occurred in London. Just 544 were solved.

In Hertfordshire, in 2020, 915 cases were recorded; in South Yorkshire, the figure was 669. No one was charged in either police area in that year.

The Liberal Democrats have called for more to be done to crack down on the problem, including more visible community policing to deter thieves.

cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26200897

'Theft epidemic'

The party said the Conservatives' 2019 manifesto promise to recruit 20,000 more police officers by March 2023 had stalled.

Home Office figures show that by 30 September, 15,343 extra officers had been recruited.

Richmond Park MP, and Lib Dem Treasury spokesperson, Sarah Olney said: "There is a catalytic converter theft epidemic across many parts of the country, but far too often the gangs responsible are getting away with it.

"At the very least, people should be able to expect that if something is stolen from their vehicle it will be properly investigated."

Victims were "not just massively inconvenienced but often left out of pocket and hit by higher insurance costs", she added.

The cost of replacing a catalytic converter is put at between £150 and £800, depending on the type of car and the complexity of the job.

cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26200905

Crime prevention

A Home Office spokesperson said: "We recognise the impact that theft can have on victims and we want offenders charged and brought to justice in the courts.

"Since the National Infrastructure Crime Reduction Partnership was set up in 2020, there has been significant success in tackling metal theft through co-ordinated national action against scrap metal dealers - including a marked increase in enforcement action from police and partner agencies."

During two weeks of national action to tackle catalytic converter and other metal theft, 64 arrests were made and more than 1,000 converters and other stolen items were recovered, the spokesperson added.

Police say that although catalytic converter thefts are increasing, there are steps that can be taken to protect a vehicle.

They suggest asking a car dealer for advice on approved locks or guards, registering the converter and marking it with a forensic marker.

Alternatively, they say, try to make sure the vehicle is parked in a garage overnight, or in a secure compound if it is a commercial vehicle.

Otherwise, police add, park in an area that is well-lit and overlooked, and try to park so the converter can not be easily reached by potential thieves. Vehicles that sit high above the road are said to be particularly vulnerable.

END

1/?

i've been reading a lot about this topic this past year or two and people have always known what the problem was, and although they were correct, the problems that they pointed out were only ever individual parts of the full problem
there were multiple reasons which compounded over the years until it reached a breaking point when it finally became 100% unsustainable, economically speaking

>first reason
all the car manufacturers here were owned by foreign companies
it is impossible for a country to have a healthy, functioning industry when so much of it is decided by a foreign country and the factors there
if people yearn for a sports sedan and a domestic company isn't allowed to create one because the parent company overseas doesn't care for it, that sends a message of carelessness that is never a good sign for either company
we were always unable to keep up with market trends as a result of that because the foreign executives simply didn't want to invest the time or money into such a small market even if the cars were as high quality as the ones in their own country; patriotism still exists in the car industry albeit in random doses
we had a small chance to buy back our own car manufacturers in 2008 with the GFC but then the american government bailed out their own failing car manufacturers with billions of taxpayer dollars and we were left without a clue because our politicians were too slow on the trigger
the ultimate issue in my opinion with this reason is that we were never allowed to expand outside of australia so we never got to properly compete in the world market which means we will never understand what kind of market share australian cars would have had overseas as all we ever had was imported cars which only highlighted the trends in our own individual market, never vice versa
if we were allowed to compete overseas it might have highlighted problems which needed addressing but leadership never cared

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
2/?

>second reason
our ability to make cars was never really that great
even in a country like britain where most car manufacturers are owned by foreign companies, there are still huge differences:
britain is located a stone's throw from europe which is full of quality technology, knowledge and manpower in the automotive industry
britain itself has a massive car industry that is capable of success and prestige because they too have quality technology, manpower and knowledge reserves, especially since tons of it comes directly from motorsport which brits excel at
so as they are surrounded by established world famous automakers, as they themselves are, being owned by foreign companies is not as large of a problem as it was for us

we never really got to stretch our legs properly when it came to designing and manufacturing cars after the 1970s when most cars in our lineups were just badge engineered cars from the US, europe and japan - literally every single car except for maybe two or three out of a dozen for both holden and ford were just foreign cars with holden/ford badges by 2005 - "our" car companies were full of non-australian cars and the ones that we actually did design and manufacture both shared almost the exact same segment in the market - family sedans with powerful engines - how catastrophically stupid it was to have two of the very few domestic cars compete long-term for the same spot in the market
and the physical and visual quality wasn't even that good since clearly a lot of the money was spent on the engines, everything else in the car fell apart or was poorly put together: the design of the centre console, the material on the touch points, the general exterior design was often outdated and many standard features in foreign cars (outside of the engine) were missing in australian cars like child safety locks, ABS, ESC, TC, power windows, etc., even the most basic things like fuel cap doors would fall off as recently as the early 2000s

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
3/?

>even the most basic things like fuel cap doors would fall off as recently as the early 2000s
this was mainly due to the strong protectionism which led to a lazy company culture which fell behind while the rest of the world rocketed forward in terms of innovation and quality, also combined with the other reasons which i will mention

>third reason
what i said above leads into the next reason: the strong protectionism in the form of tariffs and taxes
in the 1960s, tariffs on imported cars was over 40%, that was of course to help australian cars thrive - but why? were our cars not good enough to survive on their own merits? well it turns out that no amount of tariffs will stop people from buying cars which local manufacturers don't have because people are moving away from large cars and want smaller, more economical cars
critics of industry protection have always argued that it leads to inefficiency and lacking incentives to invest in high technology and high quality products and they were proven completely right
and the cherry on top is that foreign car manufacturers completely bypassed the tariffs by setting up factories here to produce cars locally
by the 1980s, the tariffs were almost gone and it was at this point that the government already had plans to slowly wind down local manufacturing year-by-year to ensure a smooth, relatively painless process - that didn't happen because of political reasons and instead of trying to quickly scale up and innovate rapidly to create low volume, high quality products which is how many manufacturers survive, we did none of that
this also ties into the first reason which is that a massive chunk of profits went to foreign car manufacturers instead of staying here so the government was forced to spend more money to keep the industry afloat compared to other countries
in the end we had cars that were more expensive to build and buy as well as having lower quality compared to foreign equivalents

posts.sub: Auto Executives Are Losing Confidence In EV Adoption
posts.com:
A new survey found executives are concerned about inflation and ongoing supply chain problems.

Automaker executives across the world are increasingly growing concerned about the rate of electric vehicle adoption than they were only a year ago due to ongoing supply chain issues and rising inflation. Per CNBC, the annual global auto survey of 915 executives from KPMG, an international consulting and accounting firm, has found that 76% of them are troubled by the economy and high interest rates and how both will affect their business in 2023. US-based auto executives are even more concerned with 84% reporting back.

The bottom line is that auto execs are becoming less bullish about the number of pure battery electric vehicles in and outside of the US by 2030. For example, last year's survey of EV global sales estimates by 2030 ranged from 20% to 70%.

This year, those numbers were down from 10% to 40%. Here in the US, the median sales expectation for EVs was 35% of the new vehicle market. In 2021, it was 65%. Why is this a problem for the US government?
Because the Biden administration is aiming for a 50% adoption rate by 2030.

"There's still a sense of optimism long term, and yet, most importantly, there's a sense of realism in the near term. You see this realism throughout the entire survey," Gary Silberg, KPMG's global head of automotive, told the new outlet. "You can be long-term optimistic, but near term, you've got to be very realistic," he added. "It's not rainbows and butterflies and euphoria anymore, it's game on."

Aside from economic and supply chain concerns, auto execs are nervous about stricter requirements for federal tax credits when purchasing new EVs as well as rising prices for raw materials for batteries. Dealerships are also continuing to mark up EV prices by thousands of dollars due to low inventory.


https://carbuzz.com/news/auto-executives-are-losing-confidence-in-ev-adoption

>fire truck up for an oil change
>hoping to get to drive it this winter as ive been neglecting it for a few years now
>fire it up
>idles at 2k
>shut it off
>unplug idle air motor
>500rpm idle to limp it around
>drive it down the street
>it won't shift or shifts nonsensically
>read about symptoms
>talk to frens
>theyre saying that either it's a vaccum leak or tps
>read about voltage range for tps
>it's like 0.5 to 5v
>check it with throttle shut
>3v
>order a new tps
>install it
>truck run happy and shifts now
happy truck

posts.name: PackardAnon
posts.com:
>>26189116
Man do I love wiring on old cars. I've been going through the diagram for the Packard; the car is like, 70 wires max. $100 of wire and crimps, and a fuse block gets me a brand new harness.

In other news, I've been diagnosing the overdrive on the car. It's got an R9 unit; it's pretty simple, but it has its quirks. It's got this kickdown switch which grounds the distributor, and that wire is cut (gee, I wonder why lol). The primary Energizer is a centrifugal governor that I'm pretty sure is burned up, and it goes into a dual-coil relay that controls a solenoid with two windings (pull-in, and hold-in). I checked the solenoid, I know it's good; I'm gonna test the relay to make sure it works, jumper past the governor (which is on the ground side funnily enough), and see if I don't get a click. Wish me luck!

On normal passenger vehicles, vans, pickups? Not unless the conditions are absolutely horrible, and in a lot of those cases it'll be the amount of snow stopping you, not the slipperiness

If you've got the worst possible surface, aka ice with water ontop, then good chains with preferrably sharper "stud edges" can be of immense help, given you have the weight needen to make use of them

However, coming from a place with heavy, long, and snowy winters where the roads are ice and snow for 6 months of the year, and where pretty much everyone uses top-tier winter tires (both studded and studless) I never see anyone use chains outside of big semi's, wheel loaders, and tractors. Some danish tourists still use them as they often do not have tires suited for the norwegian winter, but they tend to be of the very light variant - and are usually sufficient

posts.sub: Did I make a big mistake? 2023 Forester
posts.com:
So my car broke and I spent a good two months looking at used ones. I got really tired of people trying to fuck me over with $20,000 RAV4s with 110k miles, cars in "mint condition" with actual rats living inside of them, etc. I live on top of a mountain, which snows a lot, so I want AWD, and I need an SUV due to the equipment I use in my hobbies.

I make $83,000/yr and am buying a $36k Forester Premium. Paying MSRP with no dealer accessories. I felt while it stretched my budget a little bit, I can more than afford it (I know, that's what poor people say) - and it's better value than dealing with the used car market around here.

Lightly used foresters around here are still going for MSRP. On top of that, I work from home and only drive a couple days a week to go shooting or whatever, so I'll put very few miles on it. I figure in my case, especially given the area I live in I shouldn't get hit too hard by depreciation.. especially since there's people around here who would pay extra to not wait 3 months for an order.

But still, I am paying 15% of my take-home pay on a vehicle. When I asked plebbit, they all told me I was a fucking moron. But with the car payment and insurance factored in, my complete monthly expenses would be $2400.. I'd have $2200 left over. I feel that means I'm not stretching my budget too much.

Thoughts?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26202040
>reliability overblown
Anything can be overblown on the internet, but these do stand head and shoulders above their contemporaries. It's the build quality that is the real virtue though.
Shut the door of one, listen and feel it, and get back to me. For that matter, use the hazard lights switch of an early one as well. Oh, and check out the wear profile of MB-tex w123 seats at 300k miles. Oh and try to find a w123 whose factory rustproofing under the floorpans wore through (they will only rust from water pooling above; inside the car). It is true that these cars will die eventually if totally neglected, but there are stories of them running with a knock so bad it eats an entire piston until there is just a gnarled conrod left, and still going. It is true that some modern cars can pretty easily make 300k, maybe even some current German cars, but nothing at the price point of an E-class is built overall to the level of craftsmanship today that these were back then. And when parts do fail, the parts themselves are usually able to be disassembled and repaired e.g. replacing o-rings in the self leveling suspension valve, or replacing a simple check valve in the vacuum pump. Granted, they were also ~$32k in the early 1980s but much of that is due to crazy exchange rates with the deutschmark.

Picrel: the turbo compressor wheel of my previously neglected car at 330k miles when I got it; no intercooler to catch that debris that obviously left, but all cylinders still had compression within 5% of factory acceptable tolerance. Ran totally fine just didnt make any boost.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26202154
Its gonna be real slow. You mostly change your driving style to compensate so people dont honk at you. A big factor is often at this age/neglect that the auto transmissions can have issues shifting at appropriate times which makes the car slower. A total basketcase 4cyl nonturbo with broken automatic may take 30-40s to reach 60mph if it does get there. With properly tuned motor and transmission you can floor it, spool boost, and keep up with modern econoboxes and usually pass traffic. Top speed is about 95-105mph for 5cyl nonturbo and turbo respectively which isn't terrible. You can be in the fast lane on the highway until 300hp+ cars come up quick behind you. A 4 cyl non turbo will usually top out at 80-85mph though.

What's fascinating for me is the sheer variety of machines during this era of sports car racing. Especially in the early days of BPR and Le Mans before the manufacturers flooded in.
In GT1 you had oddities like
>Aston Martin DB7 LM GT1
>Bugatti EB110SC
>Callaway C7R
>Chevy Corvette C4 ZR-1
>De Tomaso Pantera GT1
>Jaguar XJ220C
>Lotus Esprit GT1
>Nissan 300ZX IMSA
>Renault Spider GT1
>Porsche 911 GT2 Evo

And over in GT2, you have even weirder shit
>Callaway Supernatural Corvette LM
>Ferrari 348 and 355s
>Marcos LM600
>Morgan Plus 8 GTR
>Saleen Mustang GT2
>VBM 4000 GTC
>Venturi 400/500/600LM

Half of them weren't anywhere near competitive against the F40s and later the Mclaren F1s but it's interesting to see what smaller teams would throw together in a shitbox to try and make them work.
It's sad that something like this will probably never be replicated again.

Whoever this is is moron talking out of his ass and doesn't understand that technical regulations don't stay static for decades. Rules change and cars can be eligible for different categories. The McLaren F1 didn't race under the same GT1 regs in 1997 as it did in the years prior. The Toyota GT-One was recategorized as a GTP when GT1 was cancelled. The Viper GTS/R raced as a GT1 in its first year, then rehomologated as a GT2. It'd also race under the IMSA/ACO rules in the GTS category. Then you had the Maserti MC-12 which didn't conform to re-vamped GT1 regs of mid-'00s, but was granted homologation on a waiver anyway because Mosley demanded it.

The main takeaway is that rules change and different racing series can categorize cars as they see fit. GT1 in 1994 was not the same as GT1 in 2005 or GTS in 2001 or GT in 2003. They are all different rule sets.

>>26194907
The desolation in sportscar racing caused by the subsequent collapse of Gr.C (and Gr.B a few years before) led to fans looking at more national-level and single-make series to get their fix. Under these circumstances, Venturi made their own one-make series in 1992 called the Gentleman Driver's Trophy for amateurs which garnered a lot of attention despite being side-events for bigger races. The series used their 400 Trophy racecar and got a lot of response from teams. In charge of the series was Venturi's head of competition services, Stephane Ratel, who is practically the godfather of the modern GT era. In 1993, facing a dwindling prototype field, the ACO allowed production-based cars to fill the rest of the grid for the first time since 1986. The response to their Trophy series and a chance for competing at the LM24, Venturi stepped up to the plate with the 500LM and were represented by no less than 7 cars. They didn't win, but most of the cars actually succeeded in finishing the race.

In 1994, Ratel teamed up with Jurgen Barth and Patrick Peter to make the BPR series which would aim to become the first intercontinental sportscar series since Gr.C folded. Ratel would apply his connections from the Trophy series to get teams to race in BPR giving Venturi a strong presence in a field that would otherwise be a slew of 911s and a single F40 for most of the races. The BPR would continue to grow in 1995 and 1996 with Venturi competing every year until it was taken over by the FIA. During the BPR years Ratel would form the SRO which has been shaping GT racing for almost 30 years.

>>26195544
First, nice Double-Dubs.

Second, something to add was that the performance spike and extremely high running costs of Group C & GTP cars in America in the early 1990s lead to many privateer teams and gentlemen drivers to look elsewhere, which in turn lead to a rise in One-Make series like the Porsche Super Cup and the Ferrari Challenge series. The head if Porsche's competition department at the time? Jurgen Barth.

The biggest mover and shaker in the Ferrari Challenge series when it launched in the 1990s? Patrick Peter.

By early 1993, Stephane Ratel, Barth and Peter started organizing special race weekends where teams in their one-make series that were up for it raced against each other. By Le Mans that year, the BPR GT series was starting to take shape and they just so happened to use the rulebook Le Mans came up with for 1994.

I think Peter's clout back in the '90s was promoting events, especially vintage motorsport. Before BPR, his organization brought back the modern interpretation of the French Tour Auto event in 1992. He would later go on to start the Le Mans Classic in the early-'00s. His connection was useful in filling up the grid as many teams were just amateur drivers that owned or maintained classic racecars.

Barth was basically just famous for his career as a Porsche factory driver having 4 class wins at LM24 with one of those being an outright win in a 936. He was just there to put a famous face on the series and his final class win happened just months before the first BPR race. Essentially the spokesman, he held a lot of celebrity sway over Porsche enthusiasts (and probably why so many teams on the grid were driving Porsches)

Ratel was the main guy running the whole operation. He also used his connections at Venturi to get teams from the Trophy series to sign on to BPR and step up the Trophy cars to one of the new 500LM racecars.

3.5 hrs covering every single undeniable proof that it was faked. And due to your false-equivalency, they specifically call out to not be associated with flat earthers in the intro card.

There were a million reasons to fake the moon landing:

-NASA had sunk ungodly amounts of money and to have failed would've made the American public lose all faith in the US Government and most science, not to mention we would've been the laughing stock of the world.

-It was important for the US to beat Russia during the cold war outside of actual combat to maintain a "don't fuck with us" persona

-It created a ton of hope in the general path forward for humanity, most of the optimism for the rest of the millennium was coasting on the optimism of the moon landing.

I'm not surprised in the least why they faked it knowing the consequences of admitting they couldn't do it, but it's 50 years in the rear view mirror and it's more and more apparent every day that we never went because despite all advances in science and computers no one has a fucking clue how to get there today. Literally everything else done by 1970 has been reverse engineered and replicated by the lowest of shit-tier countries, yet even the best rival space programs have yet to even have a solid guess of how to get to the moon and back in one piece. And you know how they keep saying "herp derp, we went to the moon on a computer less powerful than a modern calculator!", yeah, it's cuz we didn't.

>>26071719
Nissan has bungled its exit from the FIA World Endurance championship as badly as it handled competing in the fiercely competitive sports cars series.

Approximately 40 employees at the Indianapolis-based LMP1 program were notified by e-mail the program had been cancelled Tuesday morning, yet with many of the staffers on vacation for the holidays and away from work e-mail, news of the firing, for some, came from a press release the Japanese brand decided to post in its global newsroom. Those who did turn up for work Tuesday morning were barred access to the building, and senior team officials, who were also caught by surprise, stepped in to call and inform (or confirm) the sudden dismissals for all who worked at the facility.

Nissan's cancelation of the troubled program, just days before Christmas, is the latest chapter in what has been a truly tumultuous journey from concept to race.

Road & Track was present for the Nissan GT-R LM NISMO's debut on Dec. 19, 2014, at Circuit of The Americas, where the radical, front-engine, front-wheel-drive prototype suffered through a troubled introduction that made only modest gains over the next 368 days until the program's termination. https://www.roadandtrack.com/motorsports/news/a27710/nissan-fired-its-lmp1-employees-over-e-mail/

>>26075559
Pretty much..
“Behind the engine and beneath the cockpit is a kinetic energy recovery system using two flywheels developed by Torotrak. The flywheels gain energy from the use of the front brakes then discharges that energy back to the front wheels via a driveshaft running over the top of the combustion engine. The flywheels can also output power to a secondary driveshaft which is connected to a limited-slip differential at the rear of the car which feeds epicyclic gearboxes located in each rear wheel hub, allowing the GT-R to be all-wheel drive if necessary.”

Sound complicated? It should, because it is.

Additionally, while the engine is in front of the driver, it’s also behind the centerline of the front wheels, so it’s more of a front-mid layout. As Bowlby explained in an interview with Racecar Engineering:

“The front tyres on the Nissan GT-R LM NISMO are bigger than the rear tyres – 14 inch wide front vs. 9 inch rear. This is due to the way that mass is distributed in the car. We have moved the weight bias forwards to give us traction for the front-engined, front-wheel drive. We’ve also moved the aero forwards so we’ve moved the capacity of the tyres forward to match the weight distribution. So the aero centre of pressure, the mass centre of gravity and the tyre capacity are all in harmony and that means we have bigger tyres at the front than the rear”

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26068883
Mitsubishi Motors completely abandoned RWD cars with the exception of the Starion in the 1980s. This would be one of the many decisions that would bleed the brand over the next few decades.
When the big three of Japan decided to come out with their bespoke luxury brands, Mitsubishi decided there was no need for this despite having basically no clout in the American market, they made fleet and commuter vehicles. This combined with the pathetic 3.0 V6 meant the gussies up Galant known as the Sigma was a failure.
They also gradually fucked up their sports car lineup in the states as well. The DSM cars, Chrysler's FWD sports cars, and the captive import Starion (Chrysler Conquest), occupied slightly varying price levels but were essentially in competition with each other in the same showrooms.
The GTO/3000GT used a twin-turbo version of the 6G72 3.0 V6 in the highest trims. We know now that even this engine struggled to power the AWD system of the over 3500 lb car which wasn't helped by the two turbochargers. What's stranger is that the 6G74 3.5 V6 was dropped in multiple Mitsubishi vehicles, SUVs and sedans, and was able to approach the twin-turbo 6G72 in power in NA form.
During the height of the Fast and Furious tuner hype, Mitsubishi cut corners and made the third generation Eclipse FWD only, but let you have a V6.
The company would spend the 2000s and 2010s producing shitty commuter cars for the states, the market they invested so much into entering through the Chrysler partnership. By the 2010s they were essentially a second class Jap brand like Suzuki and Isuzu.

The biggest issue with the LMP-07 was that it was built around an engine that was designed for formula cars, so its natural vibrations basically shook the car apart. It's first race was the best one, because it was held on a flat, featureless "Roval" and the vibration issues weren't bad enough to cause mechanical failures.

A privateer team modified it in 2002 and went with a completely different engine, but the car wasn't much more competitive and rule changes to outlaw at the end of the season.

>Wasn't there a mythbusters about this?
It was about a different topic.

And it is an easy mistake for consumers to think that "gasoline is all the same". It is not. Gasoline does not have an exact set of percentage numbers that it is processed to before being sold to you. The quality and content of crude oil varies greatly even if it is crude from the same well. The refineries get crude from different places and separate and crack and refine it until the gasoline product is good enough to be sold. But the percentages of xylenes, toluene, benzene, butane, pentane etc, can vary from batch to batch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26191920
>What's considered top/low tier?
For top tier brands, Shell V-Power Nitro+ has the most detergent at approx 7X. Costco is the next at 5X. Other brands may have as low as 2.5X as they are at the bottom of the top tier brands. Nevertheless, top tier will always be the better tier because it sets a maximum on how much sulfur and other contaminants can be in the gasoline.

Low-sulfur crude oil (aka Sweet Crude) costs more than regular crude oil that has more sulfur in it. That sulfur requires additional refining to lower it to the point where it qualifies as normal regular gasoline. Top tier regular gasoline requires an even lower sulfur content than specified by the regular gasoline standard.

>>26192124
The issue is "minimum octane rating", as it clearly states on the pump.
My cars needs 93.
But the highest locally is "91".
I get detonation from citgo (7-11) "91" but not other brands of "91".
Agitation lowers octane raring because oxygen is dissolved into the fuel. The farther a gas station is from a refinery, the lower the octane because of the 18 wheeler fuel truck bouncing down the highway.
So to tankers can be filled in sequence at the refinery with 95 octane, but the one that unloads at a gas station 250 mikes away might have 93 octane but the one that delivers to a station 600 miles away has 91 octane by the time he gets there.

posts.sub: seriously, does oil stop leak work?
posts.com:
If you look on amazon at AT 205 reseal for example. it's mostly positive, but if you read negative reviews, people have absolute nightmare stories that it turned their seals into mush, or that the seals completely fell off. that they needed their entire transmission rebuilt or something like that.

Basically my 325i has a leak. it's not catastrophic. i can just top it off every couple weeks. That's what I've been doing for a long time. I don't even know where it's coming from. I was going to clean everything and then put UV dye in to find the source of the leak but it's just too cold now so i said F it.

I just don't like that it drips if I park in somebody's driveway or something like that.

I just replaced the head gasket and valve cover gasket a few months ago so I don't think it's those. It's probably the oil pan gasket or the rear main seal, which are both jobs that I don't really want to do. You have to remove the axles to remove the oil pan.

And RMS is probably more than I can do by myself in my garage with hand tools so that's why I want to try a stop leak but I can't risk making the problem worse.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26200694
>196k miles
I personally would not. I bought mine for $4k 8 months ago with only 112k miles on it. AMA I guess.

If you're dead set:
>IMS bearing
a massively overblown problem for the '98 model year. I wouldn't avoid a '98 for that reason alone
>AOS
can be troublesome but won't strand you if you're not retarded (just look for smoke and keep an eye on cold crank exhaust color / duration)
>rear main seal, bore scoring
not issues for '98s
>D-chunk, porous block, timing chain tensioners
also not widespread issues

things to actually look for:
>when was the clutch replaced (if original, ignore or low ball even further) (if auto, stay away)
>very regular oil changes (offer to change the oil filter before buying at your cost, tear open the filter and look for metal shavings)
>water pump & low temp coolant valve (crank and let idle til temp stabilizes, odds are it'll idle hot indicating spent coolant, bad sensors, or failing water pump)
>HVAC foam (kills heat) (check the vents for little scraps of grey foam, this indicates loss of baffle foam) (run the heat, if it doesn't get piping hot quick, it's goofed)
>integrity of soft top window
>convertible mechanism grinding noises & arm alignment
>check all vac and fuel hoses
>listen to aux belt pulleys
>check integrity of underbody and passenger side intake fan

In my mind, a “technician” is a parts monkey - he can read codes, and throw parts at a problem until it gets fixed.

A “mechanic” is a man who can diagnose a problem (code or no code,) and will actually dig into a problem so he can fix it right the first damn time. (A code merely tells you where to start looking. “EGR Valve Position Sensor Circuit Failure” could mean EGR valve, the sensor, or the wiring itself. Or any of a number of connections in that circuit.)

Most wrenches these days are “techs” - they expect OBD to do the work for them. Real “mechanics” are a dying breed.

>>26200321
This is literally not true, you're incorrectly attributing definitions based on your personal experience with specific local businesses and what they called the person working on the car. A technician is someone that assembles, diagnoses, and repairs equipment, period, and that's exactly what a mechanic is. It's no different from micrometer and micron, they are the same measurement with micron being the more slang word.

Now, if you want to compare dealership mechanics vs. independent mechanics, yes, there's a difference. Dealerships will only replace because they know their customers, above all else, don't want to have the problem re-occur and are more willing to spend more for the repair. Independent mechanics know they are typically dealing with people that want to spend less and are more likely to roll the dice on a repair not permanently fixing the problem to save money upfront. Independent shops also tend to have people more familiar with older cars because it's the same guy that's been in business for 30+ years vs a dealer where every mechanic is no more than 5 years out of trade school and is literally younger than a 25 year old car let alone worked on one before. Fixing can sometimes work out and save money, but it's always a dice roll. Although, sometimes replacing doesn't always work either because they cheaped out after the initial part run and the replacements are inferior, this is the case with some C5 Corvette parts as you're better off rebuilding the original part than getting the cost-cut replacement.

There's nothing the trucking industry hates more than change, especially expensive change. This is why in the US the majority of new power units and trailers are still spec'd with S-cam drums. ADB are superior in nearly every way, but have a higher upfront cost and overall maintance cost (at least here in the rust belt where calipers fail all the time and are a grand a piece)
Not even getting into the fact there are no charging stations for these things, there is no maintence network. There's no network of Tesla service dealers throughout the most commonly used trucking routes. Kenworth/Peterbilt/Volvo/Mack/Mercedes/International/Western Star all have these, so do Cummins, Cat, Detroit, ect...
But the biggest issue with them, is that they clearly did not talk to anyone who drives a truck for a living about the interior design. Holy shit is it awful.

>>26192509
Acceleration is kind of whatever.
The real benefit is in cost savings.
Apparently just by switching from diesel to electricity can save up to $200,000 over the life cycle of the truck.
Then there’s the benefits in maintenance where it has fewer moving parts, less can go wrong, etc. etc.
The regenerative braking also really helps the truck on the downhill, as it virtually eliminates the possibility of the truck going runaway.

The central issue is mainly in the range of course.
It isn’t a deal killer as there are a lot of scenarios where it’s range is fine.
For example with Pepsi, one of the customers, they only need trucks that go 100-200 miles.
This is because they’ve built all their liquified corn syrup factories within 100 miles of each other already.
But if you are doing long haul’s it’s range is pretty much a deal killer.
For long hauling it will need at least 800-1000 miles of range to work.
About double what it currently has.

Also the interior is a bit weird.
Supposedly Tesla had a team of truckers they consulted for this truck, but the interior really seems to say otherwise?
It’s center seated, which is weird because truckers are used to backing up from a left hand seat.
Also it’s lacking support for radio communications, which you need as a trucker or some sites won’t let you deliver because you can’t communicate with the loading teams.
Sone very noobish oversights with the interior.

>A Floridian homeowners association doesn’t want one of its members to park their new all-electric Rivain R1T outside.

>The HOA in question is that of Weston Hills Country Club just west of downtown Fort Lauderdale. Now, just two weeks after receiving his new truck, the HOA sent a letter citing the following rule.

>“Trucks, trailers, Recreational Vehicles (RVs) and/or commercial vehicles of any kind are not permitted to be parked anywhere… except inside of your garage during overnight hours.” Gordon says that “These were written in the 1980s by Arvida and it said no trucks and no vans. Since then, trucks have become a popular vehicle for personal use.”

>He’s right. Oftentimes, trucks are less about actually hauling, towing, or working than they are about being a status symbol these days. To that end, you’d think that the HOA would appreciate having a $100,000 status symbol out in the neighborhood for all to see. Evidently, that’s far from the case.

>The president of the HOA left Local 10 News a voicemail saying “If the gentleman would have read the documents when he bought the house, he would have seen that and there is a possibility that he would not have bought the truck.” At the very least it seems a bit silly for an HOA to take issue with a Rivian R1T parked outdoors when the clip from Local10 shows a Kia Telluride and an old Mazda 3 parked on the same street.

>Either way, Gordon’s attorney points out that a similar case saw a truck owner sue his HOA. When the plaintiff won, the HOA not only had to allow the truck to be parked where it was but also had to pay attorney’s fees of some $40,000. “Is there anything that is going to make you get rid of that vehicle?” Gordon was asked. “No,” he said. “We are ready to take it … It is just wrong.”
